metadata.ttm:title: Authorized Negotiators
metadata.ttm:desc: Users who need access to the eOffer system to work on a particular eOffer must be added as Authorized Negotiators. Multiple Negotiators may be added at one time, which is recommended practice to ensure a representative will be available to sign off on agreements with the government. Note that the Negotiator's name and email address must be entered exactly as they appear on the individual's Digital Certificate.

div.p: Any users that need to access the system to work
on an eOffer will need to be added as Authorized
Negotiators.
Basically, a negotiator can be assigned one of two
roles - One who is authorized to sign and one
who is not Authorized to sign.
Mandatory fields include the individual's name,
title, phone number, and e-mail.
Note that the name and e-mail address of the
person you are assigning must appear exactly as it
does on that person's digital certificate or the
system will not allow them access.
These fields will initially be populated
from your digital certificate.
Begin by entering the user's title.
The eOffer system allows both domestic and
international phone numbers.
The "domestic" field must be a ten digit number with
hyphens separating the area code as well as the
last four digits.
The system has no required formatting when entering
an international number.
You may also enter the user's fax number, if
desired.
The "Role" drop down menu requires a bit of
explanation.
A negotiator who is not authorized to sign may
prepare or work on an offer and submit it.
The offer will need to be signed later by someone
with signing authority A negotiator who IS
authorized to sign may prepare an offer, sign it
and submit it.
This person, essentially, has been granted the
authority to bind the company into agreements
with GSA.
If you are working with a consultant to prepare your
offer, it is up to you whether to grant that
consultant the authority to sign or not.
Every offer needs to have at least one "Authorized
to Sign" negotiator.
A best practice is to have two or more, in the event
that something happens to one of the negotiators
during a time-sensitive process.
It is in your best interest to review your
negotiators, monthly, and make sure all information
is up to date.
Click "Add This Negotiator" when you have
finished entering the required information.
This will take you to the "Authorized Negotiator"
screen.
From here, you can Edit or Delete the information for
an existing negotiator.
You can also Add a New Negotiator Click the "Save
and Continue" button when you're ready to move on.
